prompt:
I have the following count table for an RNA-seq experiment, rows are genes and columns are samples, "Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx". The first column of the file is my gene names and the rest of the columns are samples. My annotation data is here  "SRP021193.colData.tsv", it contains sample annotations and rows of this matches the columns of count table, first column is the sample ids. Normalize counts, make two PCA plots for samples, one color coded samples by "group" and the other color coded by "LibrarySelection" in my annotation data.

here are first few lines of the file(s).

Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx:
Genes	CASE_1	CASE_2	CASE_3	CASE_4	CASE_5	CASE_6	CTRL_1	CTRL_2	CTRL_3	CTRL_4	CTRL_5	CTRL_6
TSPAN6	9832	25521	23529	0	32	0	10558	20573	6507	0	0	 0
TNMD	3281	 7167	 3435	0	 0	0	  202	  403	 203	0	0	21


SRP021193.colData.tsv:
diagnosis	group	LibrarySelection
CASE_1	non-ischemic cardiomyopathy	CASE	cDNA


response:
I apologize for the error in the previous code. It stands to reason that DESeq cannot handle missing values in the design formula. To address this issue, we need to eliminate any rows of the metadata that contain NAs (missing values). Please see the modified code below:

```
# Load necessary packages
library(DESeq2)
library(readxl)
library(readr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggfortify)

# Read the count data
count_data <- read_excel("Supplementary_Table_1_exp.xlsx")
count_data$Genes <- make.unique(as.character(count_data$Genes))
rownames(count_data) <- count_data$Genes
count_data <- count_data[, -1]

# Read the metadata
col_data <- read_tsv("SRP021193.colData.tsv")

# Remove NAs from metadata
col_data <- col_data[complete.cases(col_data), ]

# Ensure count_data and col_data have the same samples
common_samples <- intersect(colnames(count_data), rownames(col_data))
count_data <- count_data[, common_samples]
col_data <- col_data[common_samples, ]

# Create DESeqDataSet
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromMatrix(countData = as.matrix(count_data), 
                              colData = col_data, 
                              design = ~ group)

# Normalize the counts
dds_norm <- estimateSizeFactors(dds)

# PCA for samples, color coded by "group"
vsd <- vst(dds_norm, blind=FALSE)
data_frame <- plotPCA(vsd, intgroup = "group", returnData=TRUE)
percentVar <- round(100 * attr(data_frame, "percentVar"))
p <- ggplot(data_frame, aes(PC1, PC2, color = group)) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  xlab(paste0("PC1: ", percentVar[1], "% variance")) +
  ylab(paste0("PC2: ", percentVar[2], "% variance")) +
  coord_fixed()
p

# PCA for samples, color coded by "LibrarySelection"
vsd <- vst(dds_norm, blind=FALSE)
data_frame <- plotPCA(vsd, intgroup = "LibrarySelection", returnData=TRUE)
percentVar <- round(100 * attr(data_frame, "percentVar"))
p <- ggplot(data_frame, aes(PC1, PC2, color = LibrarySelection)) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  xlab(paste0("PC1: ", percentVar[1], "% variance")) +
  ylab(paste0("PC2: ", percentVar[2], "% variance")) +
  coord_fixed()
p
```

The `complete.cases()` function is employed here to remove entire rows of the metadata that have missing values. After that, it'll make sure that the count data only includes samples that are also found in the metadata. This code should eliminate the problem and allow you to generate PCA plots without any issues.
